definitions: commit oneself to and begin (an enterprise or responsibility); take on

examples.text: a firm of builders undertook the construction work

definitions: promise to do a particular thing

examples.text: the firm undertook to keep price increases to a minimum

synonyms.text: cross one's heart and hope to die

definitions: guarantee or affirm something; give as a formal pledge

examples.text: a lorry driver implicitly undertakes that he is reasonably skilled as a driver

definitions: catch up with and pass (another vehicle) while travelling on the inside

examples.text: he undertook me, at 70 mph, while on his mobile phone

shortDefinitions: catch up with and pass while travelling on the inside

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French commodite or Latin commoditas, from commodus (see commodious)

definitions: a raw material or primary agricultural product that can be bought and sold, such as copper or coffee

examples.text: commodities such as copper and coffee
a commodities broker
commodity markets

shortDefinitions: raw material or primary agricultural product that can be bought and sold

definitions: a useful or valuable thing

examples.text: water is a precious commodity

etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘sting, afflict’): from Latin stimulat- ‘urged, goaded’, from the verb stimulare

definitions: raise levels of physiological or nervous activity in (the body or any biological system)

examples.text: the women are given fertility drugs to stimulate their ovaries

shortDefinitions: raise levels of physiological or nervous activity in

definitions: encourage or arouse interest or enthusiasm in

examples.text: the reader could not fail to be stimulated by the ideas presented

shortDefinitions: encourage or arouse interest or enthusiasm in

definitions: encourage development of or increased activity in (a state or process)

examples.text: the courses stimulate a passion for learning

shortDefinitions: encourage development of or increased activity in

etymologies: Old English tōh, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch taai and German zäh

definitions: (of a substance or object) strong enough to withstand adverse conditions or rough handling

examples.text: tough rucksacks for climbers

shortDefinitions: strong enough to withstand adverse conditions

definitions: (of food, especially meat) difficult to cut or chew

examples.text: the hastily prepared steak was tough

shortDefinitions: of food difficult to cut or chew

definitions: able to endure hardship or pain

examples.text: she was as tough as old boots

shortDefinitions: able to endure hardship or pain

definitions: having the confidence and determination to cope in difficult situations

examples.text: he liked editors who were tough enough to make the grade

shortDefinitions: having confidence and determination to cope in difficult situations

definitions: difficult and requiring determination or effort

examples.text: we have six tough matches in a row

shortDefinitions: difficult and requiring determination or effort

definitions: used to express sympathy with someone in a difficult situation

examples.text: Poor kid. It's tough on her

shortDefinitions: used to express sympathy with someone in difficult situation

definitions: demonstrating a strict and uncompromising approach

examples.text: police have been getting tough with drivers
tough new laws on tobacco advertising

definitions: used to express a lack of sympathy with someone

examples.text: I feel the way I feel, and if you don't like it, tough

shortDefinitions: used to express lack of sympathy with someone

definitions: strong and prone to violence

examples.text: tough young teenagers

definitions: (of an area) notorious for violence and crime

examples.text: a tough part of the town

definitions: a rough and violent man

examples.text: a gang of toughs

definitions: endure a period of hardship or difficulty.
shortDefinitions: endure period of hardship or difficulty

synonyms.text: see it through to the end

etymologies: late Middle English (describing the animating principle of living beings, also in vital (sense 2 of the adjective)): via Old French from Latin vitalis, from vita ‘life’. The sense ‘essential’ dates from the early 17th century

definitions: absolutely necessary; essential

examples.text: secrecy is of vital importance
it is vital that the system is regularly maintained

definitions: indispensable to the continuance of life

examples.text: the vital organs

definitions: full of energy; lively

examples.text: a beautiful, vital girl

definitions: fatal

examples.text: the wound is vital

definitions: the body's important internal organs

examples.text: he felt the familiar knot contract in his vitals

etymologies: Old English ancleow, of Germanic origin; superseded in Middle English by forms from Old Norse; related to Dutch enkel and German Enkel, from an Indo-European root shared by angle

definitions: the part or joint connecting the foot with the leg

examples.text: Jennie fell downstairs, breaking her ankle
an ankle injury

definitions: the narrow part of the leg between the ankle joint and the calf

examples.text: her slim ankles
I stood up to my ankles in snow
ankle socks

definitions: walk

examples.text: we can ankle off to a new locale

definitions: leave

examples.text: he ankled the series to do a movie

definitions: flex the ankles while cycling in order to increase pedalling efficiency

examples.text: at higher cadences, the feet tend to flap when you are attempting to ankle

etymologies: late 18th century (earlier as chirurgical): from French cirurgical, from Old French sirurgie (see surgery)

definitions: relating to or used in surgery

examples.text: a surgical dressing
a surgical ward

shortDefinitions: relating to or used in surgery

definitions: (of a special garment or appliance) worn to correct or relieve an injury, illness, or deformity

examples.text: surgical stockings

shortDefinitions: (of special garment or appliance) worn to correct or relieve injury or deformity

definitions: done with great precision, especially with reference to a swift and highly accurate military attack from the air

examples.text: surgical bombing

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘particular’): from Latin peculiaris ‘of private property’, from peculium ‘property’, from pecu ‘cattle’ (cattle being private property). The sense ‘strange’ dates from the early 17th century

definitions: different to what is normal or expected; strange

examples.text: he gave her some very peculiar looks
Stella thought the play peculiar

definitions: slightly and indefinably unwell

examples.text: I felt a little peculiar for a while

definitions: particular; special

examples.text: any attempt to explicate the theme is bound to run into peculiar difficulties

definitions: belonging exclusively to

examples.text: some languages are peculiar to one region

definitions: a parish or church exempt from the jurisdiction of the diocese in which it lies, and subject to the direct jurisdiction of the monarch or an archbishop

examples.text: deans and canons of royal peculiars, notably Westminster Abbey and Windsor

shortDefinitions: parish exempt from jurisdiction of diocese

etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘grow weak’): from Old French fader, from fade ‘dull, insipid’, probably based on a blend of Latin fatuus ‘silly, insipid’ and vapidus ‘vapid’

definitions: gradually grow faint and disappear

examples.text: the light had faded and dusk was advancing
hopes of peace had faded

definitions: lose or cause to lose colour or brightness

examples.text: his fair hair had faded to a dusty grey
faded jeans

definitions: (of a flower) lose freshness and wither.
(of a racehorse, runner, etc.) lose strength and cease to perform well

examples.text: she faded near the finish

definitions: (of a radio signal) gradually lose intensity

examples.text: the signal faded away

definitions: (of a vehicle brake) become temporarily less efficient as a result of frictional heating

examples.text: the brakes faded, needing a firmer push to bring the car to halt

definitions: (with reference to film and television images) come or cause to come gradually into or out of view, or to merge into another shot

examples.text: fade into scenes of rooms strewn with festive remains
some shots have to be faded in

shortDefinitions: come into or out of view

definitions: (with reference to recorded sound) increase or decrease in volume or merge into another recording

examples.text: they let you edit the digital data, making it fade in and out
he skilfully fades the guitar lines up and down

definitions: (of the ball) deviate to the right (or, for a left-handed golfer, the left), typically as a result of spin given to the ball

examples.text: the ball faded toward an area left of the green

definitions: (of a golfer) cause (the ball) to deviate

examples.text: he had to fade the ball around a light pole

definitions: (in craps) match the bet of (another player)

examples.text: Lovejoy faded him for twenty-five cents

definitions: the process of becoming less bright

examples.text: the sun can cause colour fade

definitions: an act of causing a film or television image to darken and disappear gradually

examples.text: a fade to black would bring the sequence to a close

shortDefinitions: act of fading film or television image

definitions: a shot causing the ball to deviate to the right (or, for a left-handed golfer, the left)

examples.text: when they get to the 18th the ideal shot is a fade

definitions: a pass thrown so that the ball descends directly over the receiver's shoulder, especially as they veer towards the sideline

examples.text: shortly after receiving the snap, he threw a fade to Crabtree
he scores on a beautiful fade pass to the back of the end zone

shortDefinitions: pass thrown so that ball descends directly over receiver's shoulder

definitions: a haircut in which the hair is left long on top of the head but cropped close to the sides and back with the length of hair gradually decreasing

examples.text: a fade is extremely versatile and can be adjusted to different hair types and lengths

shortDefinitions: haircut in which hair is left long on top of head but cropped close to sides and back

etymologies: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French purseute ‘following after’, from pursuer (see pursue). Early senses included ‘persecution, annoyance’ and in legal contexts ‘petition, prosecution’

definitions: the action of pursuing someone or something

examples.text: the cat crouched in the grass in pursuit of a bird
those whose business is the pursuit of knowledge

definitions: a cycling race in which competitors set off from different parts of a track and attempt to overtake one another

examples.text: the Olympic pursuit champion

definitions: the action of the eye in following a moving object.
shortDefinitions: action of eye in following moving object

definitions: an activity of a specified kind, especially a recreational or sporting one

examples.text: a whole range of leisure pursuits

definitions: having, revealing, or involving a great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture

examples.text: a chic, sophisticated woman
a young man with sophisticated tastes

shortDefinitions: having, revealing, or proceeding from great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture

definitions: appealing to or frequented by people who are sophisticated

examples.text: a sophisticated restaurant

shortDefinitions: appealing to people with such knowledge or experience

definitions: (of a machine, system, or technique) developed to a high degree of complexity

examples.text: highly sophisticated computer systems

shortDefinitions: developed to high degree of complexity

definitions: (of a person or their thoughts, reactions, and understanding) aware of and able to interpret complex issues; subtle

examples.text: discussion and reflection are necessary for a sophisticated response to a text

shortDefinitions: aware of and able to interpret complex issues

definitions: a person who takes part in an organized attempt to influence legislators

examples.text: industry lobbyists pushed the government to undo the decision

shortDefinitions: person who takes part in organized attempt to influence legislators

definitions: make or become less; diminish

examples.text: the years have lessened the gap in age between us
the warmth of the afternoon lessened

definitions: a gun designed for use by one hand; a pistol.
shortDefinitions: gun designed for use by one hand

etymologies: late 16th century (referring to astral influence): from medieval Latin influentia (see influence)

definitions: having great influence on someone or something

examples.text: her work is influential in feminist psychology

shortDefinitions: having great influence on person or thing

definitions: an influential person

examples.text: young influentials
networks of influentials

definitions: separate or disconnected.
(of a house or other building) not joined to another on either side

examples.text: a four-bedroomed detached house

definitions: (of a social worker or social work) operating or based in the community rather than in an office

examples.text: detached youth workers

definitions: aloof and objective

examples.text: he is a detached observer of his own actions

etymologies: late 16th century (in the sense ‘discharge a gun’): from French détacher, earlier destacher, from des- (expressing reversal) + attacher ‘attach’

definitions: disengage (something or part of something) and remove it

examples.text: he detached the front lamp from its bracket
a willingness to detach comment from political allegiance

definitions: be easily removable

examples.text: the screen detaches from the keyboard

definitions: leave or separate oneself from (a group or place)

examples.text: a figure in brown detached itself from the shadows
the newspaper detached itself from the political parties

definitions: (of a group of soldiers or ships) be sent on a separate mission

examples.text: our crew were detached to Tabuk for the exercise

etymologies: late 17th century: from French biographie or modern Latin biographia, from medieval Greek, from bios ‘life’ + -graphia ‘writing’

definitions: an account of someone's life written by someone else.
shortDefinitions: account of someone's life written by someone else

definitions: biographies considered as a literary genre

examples.text: the basic difference of approach to autobiography and biography

shortDefinitions: writing of such type as literary genre

definitions: the course of a person's life

examples.text: although their individual biographies are different, both are motivated by a similar ambition

definitions: the subjects comprising a course of study in a school or college

examples.text: course components of the school curriculum

shortDefinitions: subjects comprising course of study in school

etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin margo, margin- ‘edge’

definitions: the edge or border of something

examples.text: the eastern margin of the Indian Ocean

definitions: the blank border on each side of the print on a page

examples.text: the notations in the margin

definitions: a line ruled on paper to mark off a margin.
an amount by which something is won

examples.text: they won by a convincing 17-point margin

shortDefinitions: amount by which something is won

definitions: an amount of something included so as to be sure of success or safety

examples.text: there was no margin for error

shortDefinitions: amount included so as to ensure success

definitions: the furthest limit of possibility, success, etc.

examples.text: the lighting is brighter than before but is still at the margins of acceptability

definitions: a profit margin

examples.text: launching these new products helped increase margins and market share

definitions: a sum deposited with a broker to cover the risk of loss on a transaction or account.
an increment to a basic wage, paid for extra skill or responsibility.
provide with an edge or border

examples.text: the plant's leaves are margined with yellow

definitions: annotate or summarize (a text) in the margins

examples.text: these he deals forth as the notable Matters, margined for better Notice

definitions: deposit an amount of money with a broker as security for (an account or transaction)

examples.text: new contracts are margined with the winnings of previously held contracts

definitions: with a lack of fear

examples.text: he fearlessly challenges the accepted version of events
I tackled fearlessly on the rugby pitch

definitions: without method or conscious decision; indiscriminately

examples.text: troops fired randomly from tanks
I randomly split the ironing into two piles

definitions: in a way that involves equal chances for each item

examples.text: each clinic surveyed 20 patients who were selected randomly
her entry was randomly drawn from around 10,000 others to win the first prize car

shortDefinitions: in way that involves equal chances for each item

definitions: the unjust or prejudicial treatment of different categories of people, especially on the grounds of ethnicity, age, sex, or disability

examples.text: victims of racial discrimination
there is widespread discrimination against women

definitions: recognition and understanding of the difference between one thing and another

examples.text: discrimination between right and wrong
young children have difficulties in making fine discriminations

definitions: the ability to judge what is of high quality; good judgement or taste

examples.text: those who could afford to buy showed little taste or discrimination

definitions: the ability to distinguish between different stimuli

examples.text: discrimination learning

shortDefinitions: ability to distinguish between different stimuli

definitions: the selection of a signal having a required characteristic, such as frequency or amplitude, by means of a discriminator.

etymologies: late 17th century: from Latin, ‘goad, spur, incentive’

definitions: a thing or event that evokes a specific functional reaction in an organ or tissue

examples.text: areas of the brain which respond to auditory stimuli

shortDefinitions: thing or event that evokes specific functional reaction

definitions: a thing that arouses activity or energy in someone or something; a spur or incentive.
shortDefinitions: thing that arouses activity or energy in person or thing

definitions: an interesting and exciting quality

examples.text: she loved the stimulus of the job

definitions: a set of temporary financial measures enacted by a government that is intended to encourage economic growth during a recession

examples.text: the stimulus was created to save 150,000 jobs

shortDefinitions: set of temporary financial measures enacted by government intended to encourage economic growth

definitions: the ability to do something successfully or efficiently

examples.text: courses to improve the competence of staff
the players displayed varying degrees of competence

definitions: the legal authority of a court or other body to deal with a particular matter

examples.text: the court's competence has been accepted to cover these matters

definitions: a person's subconscious knowledge of the rules governing the formation of speech in their first language.
shortDefinitions: subconscious knowledge of rules of one's first language

definitions: effective performance of the normal function.
an income large enough to live on, typically an unearned one

examples.text: he found himself with an ample competence and no obligations

etymologies: late 16th century: probably dialect; perhaps related to obsolete snike ‘to creep’

notes.text: The traditional standard past form of sneak is sneaked (she sneaked round the corner). An alternative past form, snuck (she snuck past me), arose in the US in the 19th century. Until very recently snuck was confined to US dialect use and was regarded as non-standard. However, in the last few decades its use has spread in the US, where it is now regarded as a standard alternative to sneaked in all but the most formal contexts. In the Oxford English Corpus there are now more US citations for snuck than there are for sneaked, and there is evidence of snuck gaining ground in British English also

definitions: move or go in a furtive or stealthy way

examples.text: I sneaked out by the back exit

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move or go in furtive or stealthy manner

definitions: convey (someone or something) in a furtive or stealthy way

examples.text: someone sneaked a camera inside

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: convey person or thing in such way

definitions: do or obtain (something) in a stealthy or furtive way

examples.text: she sneaked a glance at her watch

shortDefinitions: do or obtain something in stealthy or furtive way

definitions: creep up on (someone) without being detected

examples.text: he sneaks up on us slyly

shortDefinitions: creep up on someone without being detected

definitions: (especially in children's use) inform an adult or person in authority of a companion's misdeeds; tell tales

examples.text: she sneaked on us

shortDefinitions: inform adult or person in authority of companion's misdeeds

notes.text: The traditional standard past form of sneak is sneaked (she sneaked round the corner). An alternative past form, snuck (she snuck past me), arose in the US in the 19th century. Until very recently snuck was confined to US dialect use and was regarded as non-standard. However, in the last few decades its use has spread in the US, where it is now regarded as a standard alternative to sneaked in all but the most formal contexts. In the Oxford English Corpus there are now more US citations for snuck than there are for sneaked, and there is evidence of snuck gaining ground in British English also

definitions: (especially in children's use) someone who informs an adult or person in authority of a companion's misdeeds; a telltale

examples.text: Ethel was the form sneak and goody-goody

shortDefinitions: someone who informs adult or person in authority of companion's misdeeds

definitions: a furtive and contemptible person

examples.text: he was branded a prying sneak for eavesdropping on intimate conversation

notes.text: The traditional standard past form of sneak is sneaked (she sneaked round the corner). An alternative past form, snuck (she snuck past me), arose in the US in the 19th century. Until very recently snuck was confined to US dialect use and was regarded as non-standard. However, in the last few decades its use has spread in the US, where it is now regarded as a standard alternative to sneaked in all but the most formal contexts. In the Oxford English Corpus there are now more US citations for snuck than there are for sneaked, and there is evidence of snuck gaining ground in British English also

definitions: acting or done surreptitiously, unofficially, or without warning

examples.text: a sneak thief
a sneak preview

shortDefinitions: acting or done surreptitiously, unofficially, or without warning

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘go over a boundary or specified point’): from Old French exceder, from Latin excedere, from ex- ‘out’ + cedere ‘go’

definitions: be greater in number or size than (a quantity, number, or other measurable thing)

examples.text: production costs have exceeded £60,000

shortDefinitions: be greater in number or size than

definitions: go beyond what is allowed or stipulated by (a set limit)

examples.text: the Tribunal's decision clearly exceeds its powers under the statute

shortDefinitions: go beyond what is allowed or stipulated by

definitions: be better than; surpass

examples.text: economic growth exceeded expectations this year

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from late Latin turbulentia, from turbulentus ‘full of commotion’ (see turbulent)

definitions: violent or unsteady movement of air or water, or of some other fluid

examples.text: the plane shuddered as it entered some turbulence

shortDefinitions: violent or unsteady movement of air or water

definitions: a state of conflict or confusion

examples.text: political turbulence

etymologies: Middle English (as a verb in the senses ‘set upright’ and ‘guide, direct’, hence ‘write directions for delivery on’ and ‘direct spoken words to’): from Old French, based on Latin ad- ‘towards’ + directus (see direct). The noun is of mid 16th-century origin in the sense ‘act of approaching or speaking to someone’

definitions: the particulars of the place where someone lives or an organization is situated

examples.text: they exchanged addresses and agreed to keep in touch

definitions: the place where someone lives or an organization is situated

examples.text: our officers called at the address

definitions: a string of characters that identifies a destination for email messages or the location of a website.
a binary number that identifies a particular location in a data storage system or computer memory

examples.text: a numerical value which acts as a storage address for the data

definitions: a formal speech delivered to an audience

examples.text: an address to the European Parliament

definitions: a person's manner of speaking to someone else

examples.text: his address was abrupt and unceremonious

definitions: courteous or amorous approaches to someone

examples.text: he persecuted her with his addresses

definitions: skill, dexterity, or readiness

examples.text: he rescued me with the most consummate address

definitions: write the name and address of the intended recipient on (an envelope, letter, or parcel)

examples.text: I addressed my letter to him personally

definitions: speak to (a person or an assembly)

examples.text: she addressed the open-air meeting

definitions: name someone (in the specified way) when talking to them

examples.text: she addressed my father as ‘Mr Stevens’

definitions: say or write remarks or a protest to

examples.text: address your complaints to the Trading Standards Board

definitions: think about and begin to deal with (an issue or problem)

examples.text: a fundamental problem has still to be addressed

definitions: take up one's stance and prepare to hit (the ball)

examples.text: ensure that your weight is evenly spread when you address the ball
